Posts.Title: How do people deal with the fear? Lesley1 mthomp2020

Posts.Content: pamfenton wrote: I recently had a C/T scan to rule out mets and was told all was okay.  A week later onc called and said there was "air in the bladder".  After doing tons of research on this, and asking all the docs I know (I am a baby/OB nurse so they are not oncs or radiologists) it seems there are really only two reasons for this finding.  One is a fulminating, life threatening UTI, which I clearly don't have and U/A confirmed I do not.  I feel absolutely fine. The other is a fistula or tracking/tunneling, usually from the colon, secondary to colon cancer.  I talked to my onc yesterday and he said all he could get out of the rad, was that it was a "curious" finding.  I am thnking that I am not comfortable with "curious".  I think they should reach out to all their radiology friends and find out if this finding is ever benign(btw, when first dx'ed all MDs thought I had colon cancer as well as breast because so many hot spots showed up on PET scan.  Post polyp removal they seemed okay at last PET which was two years ago.)   I had a 5 cm tumor that was missed by these same radiologists for several years worth of mammograms. I think they owe me (and it is their medical duty) to find out more about this. Am I wrong? What should I do? What do you think?  This is all I am thinking of and need input. Pam Dx 5/17/2005, IDC, 4cm, Stage IIB, Grade 3, 1/10 nodes, ER+/PR+, HER2- Log in to post a reply
Posts.Title: "curious" C/T scan...Should I throw a fit? pamfenton pamfenton

Posts.Content: Mar 12, 2008 01:47PM pamfenton wrote: Onc just called.  He is having me see a urologist.  I asked him about the Rads kind of owing me and how is it acceptable for them to simply say "curious" and go no further.  He said he thought that is why they become rads. Interesting, eh?  So, meanwhile I got him to agree to ask any rad. he sees' have they ever heard of this as a benign finding.  He also agreed the rads. like to hide (ie , they chose that specialty so they would have no patient contact).

Posts.Content: Mar 12, 2008 01:12PM pamfenton wrote: "Get "er done", ah, if only I still lived in the south. I just checked the definition of curious, "eager to acquire knowledge or information" I am thinking maybe give the busy and very nice onc a week or so, meanwhile request a report of the scan for myself, then go with my husband to onc to plead.  If no dice, go to the radiologists...where do they hide? Prior to doing these scans (2 1/2 yrs out) I was warned they might show things you wish you hadn't known.  But is seems to me, knowledge is power.  Quicker we address this the better. Still welcoming advice.
Posts.Title: "curious" C/T scan...Should I throw a fit? pamfenton pamfenton

Posts.Content: Apr 3, 2008 05:06PM pamfenton wrote: Excellent!  Now I can tell you that one of my nursing students ( I occ. teach nursing at local com college) saw a port placement and came out saying, "Man, they are not gentle at all.  They just spread those muscles apart ...."  Yeah.  Well, that is why there are pain pills and why I don't work in surgery.   Didn't want to tell you that prior to procedure. My 22 yr old daughter broke her elbow snowboarding last week and had surgery yesterday.  5 hrs for what they thought would take 2 1/2.  Major joint fractures, really awful.Two 6 in steel plates and 3 screws she will have the rest of her life.  I am giving her so many pain pills I am up there watching her respirations constantly. It is her last semester of college( mech engineering and exercise physiology)  Forgive me but I am so proud of her, she has already been accepted to a PhD program where she will be designing implants and prosthetics for Iraqi vets. So it is so ironic she has this trama now. Sorry to ramble and brag.  I have two other kids who took the 7 yr route to finishing college...BUt, Sunshine, I am so proud of you!

Posts.Content: Mar 19, 2008 11:51PM pamfenton wrote: I know you are not as swear-wordy as I am but I have been waiting to hear the results, saw your post and just said, "F--k, f--k, f--k.  I know hair is the least of your worries but will you lose it?  I ask because I have the coolest ever headband/ponytail thing that you wear with a ball cap.  It is all human hair, very expensive and little tendrils stick out in stategic spots so you don't look bald. I will send it to you if this will be a side effect. In one of your previous posts you said something like, "I just don't know how I can do it again".  I had a very appropriate card sent to me in the worst of chemo, card was all black with white letters:  " "When you're going thru hell, you just keep going" I've never met you but I have a strong feeling about you and I back it up with my nurse's intuition.  You are going to be okay. You are going to see those boys thru college and even get married.  You are.                                   Your BC friend who would be your best friend if I lived in NC,                                                     Pam

Posts.Content: pamfenton wrote: I have had pain in my lower left leg for a week or so.  I can tell it is bone, not muscle and does not feel like any pain I've ever had before, except maybe a little similar to the growing pains when I was a kid.  More than achy, makes me limp.  Hurts most of the time but not all. What do you think?  I know I should get it checked out and will.  But anyone ever had a met to tibia?  Does it feel like this?  Could you describe the pain?
